text:
The debate about whether students should have a role in curriculum design is a contentious issue that has sparked intense discussion among educators, (1) policymakers, administrators, and scholars. While some argue that student involvement can bring numerous benefits,  to the learning process, (2) others contend that it may lead to undesirable outcomes.

On one hand, there are several compelling reasons why students should be involved in curriculum design. Firstly,2019 research suggests that when students are given a voice in shaping their educational experience they tend to feel more invested and motivated in their studies. This increased sense of ownership can lead to improved academic performance as well as enhanced overall satisfaction with their education. Furthermore involving students in curriculum design can help ensure that the material being taught is relevant and engaging to them. Students are often best placed to identify what topics and teaching methods resonate with their peers and thus can provide invaluable insights to educators. Additionally giving students a say in curriculum design can foster critical thinking skills creativity and problem-solving abilities all of which are essential for success in an increasingly complex world.

On the other hand there are also valid concerns about the potential drawbacks of involving students in curriculum design. One major concern is that students may not possess the necessary expertise or knowledge to make informed decisions about what should be included in the curriculum.
